data.v: प्रसुप्तान्निशि विश्वस्तान्यत्र ते पुरुषर्षभाः । पाञ्चालान्सपरीवाराञ्जघ्नुर्द्रौणिपुरोगमाः ॥
यत्रामुच्यन्त पार्थास्ते पञ्च कृष्णबलाश्रयात् । सात्यकिश्च महेष्वासः शेषाश्च निधनं गताः ॥
द्रौपदी पुत्रशोकार्ता पितृभ्रातृवधार्दिता । कृतानशनसंकल्पा यत्र भर्तॄनुपाविशत् ॥
द्रौपदीवचनाद्यत्र भीमो भीमपराक्रमः । अन्वधावत संक्रुद्धो भारद्वाजं गुरोः सुतम् ॥
data.md: Determined to please her, he speedily took up his club and ran in pursuit of the son of his preceptor.

data.v: भीमसेनभयाद्यत्र दैवेनाभिप्रचोदितः । अपाण्डवायेति रुषा द्रौणिरस्त्रमवासृजत् ॥
data.md: The son of Drona, out of fear of Bhima and as fate would have it discharged the celestial weapon, crying “Let it make the world free of all the Pandavas."

data.v: मैवमित्यब्रवीत्कृष्णः शमयंस्तस्य तद्वचः । यत्रास्त्रमस्त्रेण च तच्छमयामास फाल्गुनः ॥
data.md: Krishna neutralised the words by saying, “This shall not be," and Arjuna neutralised the weapon by one of his own.

data.v: द्रौणिद्वैपायनादीनां शापाश्चान्योन्यकारिताः । तोयकर्मणि सर्वेषां राज्ञामुदकदानिके ॥
गूढोत्पन्नस्य चाख्यानं कर्णस्य पृथयात्मनः । सुतस्यैतदिह प्रोक्तं दशमं पर्व सौप्तिकम् ॥
data.md: The giving birth to son by Rishi Mandapala in the womb of a bird, called Sharangi. The Adi-Parva has been described with these various matters.

data.v: अष्टादशास्मिन्नध्यायाः पर्वण्युक्ता महात्मना । श्लोकाग्रमत्र कथितं शतान्यष्टौ तथैव च ॥
data.md: These matters are dwelt with in this tenth Sauptika Parva. The great Vyasa composed it in eighteen chapters. The numbers of slokas composed in it by the great reciter of the sacred truths, is eight hundred and seventy.

data.v: श्लोकाश्च सप्ततिः प्रोक्ता यथावदभिसंख्यया । सौप्तिकैषीकसंबन्धे पर्वण्यमितबुद्धिना ॥
अत ऊर्ध्वमिदं प्राहुः स्त्रीपर्व करुणोदयम् । विलापो वीरपत्नीनां यत्रातिकरुणः स्मृतः । क्रोधावेशः प्रसादश्च गान्धारीधृतराष्ट्रयोः ॥
data.md: Then were the pathetic and heartrending lamentations of the wives of the heroes. The wrath of Gandhari and Dhritarashtra and their falling into a swoon.

data.v: यत्र तान्क्षत्रियाञ्शूरान्दिष्टान्ताननिवर्तिनः । पुत्रान्भ्रातॄन्पितॄंश्चैव ददृशुर्निहतान्रणे ॥
data.md: Then did the ladies see those heroes, their slain sons, brothers and father, lying on the field of battle.

data.v: यत्र राजा महाप्राज्ञः सर्वधर्मभृतां वरः । राज्ञां तानि शरीराणि दाहयामास शास्त्रतः ॥
data.md: The cremation of the chiefs and potentates by king Yudhishthira, the greatly wise and the foremost of all virtuous men, according to due rites.

data.v: एतदेकादशं प्रोक्तं पर्वातिकरुणं महत् । सप्तविंशतिरध्यायाः पर्वण्यस्मिन्नुदाहृताः ॥
श्लोकाः सप्तशतं चात्र पञ्चसप्ततिरुच्यते । संख्यया भारताख्यानं कर्त्रा ह्यत्र महात्मना । प्रणीतं सज्जनमनोवैक्लव्याश्रुप्रवर्तकम् ॥
अतः परं शान्तिपर्व द्वादशं बुद्धिवर्धनम् । यत्र निर्वेदमापन्नो धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः । घातयित्वा पितॄन्भ्रातॄन्पुत्रान्संबन्धिबान्धवान् ॥
data.md: Then comes the Shanti Parva, the twelfth in number, which increases the understanding. It relates the despondency of Yudhishthira.

data.v: शान्तिपर्वणि धर्माश्च व्याख्याताः शरतल्पिकाः । राजभिर्वेदितव्या ये सम्यङ्नयबुभुत्सुभिः ॥
data.md: On his having slain his fathers, brothers, sons, maternal uncles and relations by marriage. There is related how Bhishma taught laws and duties, worth the study of kings who desire to possess knowledge.

data.v: आपद्धर्माश्च तत्रैव कालहेतुप्रदर्शकाः । यान्बुद्ध्वा पुरुषः सम्यक्सर्वज्ञत्वमवाप्नुयात् । मोक्षधर्माश्च कथिता विचित्रा बहुविस्तराः ॥
data.md: If a person understands them, he attains to, consummate knowledge. The mysteries of final emancipation is also elaborately discussed.

data.v: द्वादशं पर्व निर्दिष्टमेतत्प्राज्ञजनप्रियम् । पर्वण्यत्र परिज्ञेयमध्यायानां शतत्रयम् । त्रिंशच्चैव तथाध्याया नव चैव तपोधनाः ॥
data.md: This twelfth Parva, the favourite of the wise, contains three hundred and thirty nine chapters.

data.v: श्लोकानां तु सहस्राणि कीर्तितानि चतुर्दश । पञ्च चैव शतान्याहुः पञ्चविंशतिसंख्यया ॥
अत ऊर्ध्वं तु विज्ञेयमानुशासनमुत्तमम् । यत्र प्रकृतिमापन्नः श्रुत्वा धर्मविनिश्चयम् । भीष्माद्भागीरथीपुत्रात्कुरुराजो युधिष्ठिरः ॥
data.md: The king of the Kurus, Yudhishthira was consoled by hearing the expositions of duties by the son of the Bhagirathi, Bhishma.

data.v: व्यवहारोऽत्र कार्त्स्न्येन धर्मार्थीयो निदर्शितः । विविधानां च दानानां फलयोगाः पृथग्विधाः ॥
data.md: It then treats of the rules Dharma and Artha in detail, then the various rules of charity and its different merits.

data.v: तथा पात्रविशेषाश्च दानानां च परो विधिः । आचारविधियोगश्च सत्यस्य च परा गतिः ॥
data.md: The different merits of charity according to the subjects of charity; the rules of living, the ceremonials of individual duty and the matchless merits of truth.

data.v: एतत्सुबहुवृत्तान्तमुत्तमं चानुशासनम् । भीष्मस्यात्रैव संप्राप्तिः स्वर्गस्य परिकीर्तिता ॥
data.md: All these excellent matters have been treated in this Anushasana Parva containing variety of incidents. It also describes ascension of Bhishma to heaven.

data.v: एतत्त्रयोदशं पर्व धर्मनिश्चयकारकम् । अध्यायानां शतं चात्र षट्चत्वारिंशदेव च । श्लोकानां तु सहस्राणि षट्सप्तैव शतानि च ॥
data.md: This is the thirteenth Parva which describe the certainty of righteousness. It contains one hundred and forty six chapters.

data.v: ततोऽश्वमेधिकं नाम पर्व प्रोक्तं चतुर्दशम् । तत्संवर्तमरुत्तीयं यत्राख्यानमनुत्तमम् ॥
सुवर्णकोशसंप्राप्तिर्जन्म चोक्तं परिक्षितः । दग्धस्यास्त्राग्निना पूर्वं कृष्णात्संजीवनं पुनः ॥
data.md: Who was burnt by the weapon of Ashvathama and therefore almost dead, but he was revived by Krishna; Arjuna's journey with the sacrificial horse let loose.

data.v: चर्यायां हयमुत्सृष्टं पाण्डवस्यानुगच्छतः । तत्र तत्र च युद्धानि राजपुत्रैरमर्षणैः ॥
चित्राङ्गदायाः पुत्रेण पुत्रिकाया धनंजयः । संग्रामे बभ्रुवाहेन संशयं चात्र दर्शितः । अश्वमेधे महायज्ञे नकुलाख्यानमेव च ॥
data.md: And his great risk in the fight with Babhruvahana. Then follows the story of the mongoose in the horse-sacrifice.

data.v: इत्याश्वमेधिकं पर्व प्रोक्तमेतन्महाद्भुतम् । अत्राध्यायशतं त्रिंशत्त्रयोऽध्यायाश्च शब्दिताः ॥
data.md: Thus is described the wonderful Parva, called Ashvamedhika. Its number of chapters is one hundred and three.

data.v: त्रीणि श्लोकसहस्राणि तावन्त्येव शतानि च । विंशतिश्च तथा श्लोकाः संख्यातास्तत्त्वदर्शिना ॥
data.md: The number of slokas, composed by the greatly wise Rishi, is three thousand three hundred and twenty.

data.v: तत आश्रमवासाक्यं पर्व पञ्चदशं स्मृतम् । यत्र राज्यं परित्यज्य गान्धारीसहितो नृपः । धृतराष्ट्राश्रमपदं विदुरश्च जगाम ह ॥
यं दृष्ट्वा प्रस्थितं साध्वी पृथाप्यनुययौ तदा । पुत्रराज्यं परित्यज्य गुरुशुश्रूषणे रता ॥
यत्र राजा हतान्पुत्रान्पौत्रानन्यांश्च पार्थिवान् । लोकान्तरगतान्वीरानपश्यत्पुनरागतान् ॥
ऋषेः प्रसादात्कृष्णस्य दृष्ट्वाश्चर्यमनुत्तमम् । त्यक्त्वा शोकं सदारश्च सिद्धिं परमिकां गतः ॥
data.md: His wonderful seeing of the spirits of the slain heroes through the favour of Vyasa.

data.v: यत्र धर्मं समाश्रित्य विदुरः सुगतिं गतः । संजयश्च महामात्रो विद्वान्गावल्गणिर्वशी ॥
ददर्श नारदं यत्र धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः । नारदाच्चैव शुश्राव वृष्णीनां कदनं महत् ॥
एतदाश्रमवासाख्यं पूर्वोक्तं सुमहाद्भुतम् । द्विचत्वारिंशदध्यायाः पर्वैतदभिसंख्यया ॥
सहस्रमेकं श्लोकानां पञ्च श्लोकशतानि च । षडेव च तथा श्लोकाः संख्यातास्तत्त्वदर्शिना ॥
data.md: The number of slokas, composed by the greatly wise Rishi, is three thousand three hundred and twenty.

data.v: अतः परं निबोधेदं मौसलं पर्व दारुणम् । यत्र ते पुरुषव्याघ्राः शस्त्रस्पर्शसहा युधि । ब्रह्मदण्डविनिष्पिष्टाः समीपे लवणाम्भसः ॥
data.md: It relates how on account of the Brahmana a curse, when they were all deprived of their senses with drink, those tigers of men (belonging to the Vrishni race), with many scars of battle on their bodies, slew one another on the shores of the salt-sea with Eraka grass which became deadly thunders in their hands,

data.v: आपाने पानगलिता दैवेनाभिप्रचोदिताः । एरकारूपिभिर्वज्रैर्निजघ्नुरितरेतरम् ॥
data.md: It relates how on account of the Brahmana a curse, when they were all deprived of their senses with drink, those tigers of men (belonging to the Vrishni race), with many scars of battle on their bodies, slew one another on the shores of the salt-sea with Eraka grass which became deadly thunders in their hands,

data.v: यत्र सर्वक्षयं कृत्वा तावुभौ रामकेशवौ । नातिचक्रमतुः कालं प्राप्तं सर्वहरं समम् ॥
data.md: It then relates that Rama and Krishna, after destroying their race, did not rise superior to the way of all-destroying time.

data.v: यत्रार्जुनो द्वारवतीमेत्य वृष्णिविनाकृताम् । दृष्ट्वा विषादमगमत्परां चार्तिं नरर्षभः ॥
data.md: Then is described the arrival of Arjuna, the foremost of men, at Dwarka and his sorrow and affliction seeing the city destitute of the Vrishnis.

data.v: स सत्कृत्य यदुश्रेष्ठं मातुलं शौरिमात्मनः । ददर्श यदुवीराणामापाने वैशसं महत् ॥
data.md: Performing the funeral ceremony of his maternal uncle Vasudeva, the foremost man of the Yadu dynasty, he saw the Yadu heroes lying dead where they had been drinking.

data.v: शरीरं वासुदेवस्य रामस्य च महात्मनः । संस्कारं लम्भयामास वृष्णीनां च प्रधानतः ॥
data.md: He then performed the cremation ceremonies of the illustrious Krishna and Balarama and of the other chief men of the Yadu race.

data.v: स वृद्धबालमादाय द्वारवत्यास्ततो जनम् । ददर्शापदि कष्टायां गाण्डीवस्य पराभवम् ॥
data.md: Then is described the journey of Arjuna from Dwarka with the women and children, the old and the decrepit and the great calamity he met with on the way. He also saw the overthrow of his Gandiva.

data.v: सर्वेषां चैव दिव्यानामस्त्राणामप्रसन्नताम् । नाशं वृष्णिकलत्राणां प्रभावानामनित्यताम् ॥
data.md: He also saw unpropitiousness of his celestial weapons. Seeing that it was impossible to protect the Yadu women.

data.v: दृष्ट्वा निर्वेदमापन्नो व्यासवाक्यप्रचोदितः । धर्मराजं समासाद्य संन्यासं समरोचयेत् ॥
data.md: And seeing all this, he went to Yudhishthira by the advice of Vyasa and asked permission to adopt the life of an ascetic.

data.v: इत्येतन्मौसलं पर्व षोडशं परिकीर्तितम् । अध्यायाष्टौ समाख्याताः श्लोकानां च शतत्रयम् ॥
data.md: Thus is described the sixteenth Parva, called Mausala Parva. Its number of chapters is eight and the number of slokas, composed by Vyasa, learned in truth, is three hundred and twenty. The next is Mahaprasthanika, the seventeenth Parva.

data.v: महाप्रस्थानिकं तस्मादूर्ध्वं सप्तदशं स्मृतम् । यत्र राज्यं परित्यज्य पाण्डवाः पुरुषर्षभाः । द्रौपद्या सहिता देव्या सिद्धिं परमिकां गताः ॥
data.md: It relates that the best of men, the Pandavas, abdicating their kingdom went with Draupadi in their great journey (Mahaprasthana.)

data.v: अत्राध्यायास्त्रयः प्रोक्ताः श्लोकानां च शतं तथा । विंशतिश्च तथा श्लोकाः संख्यातास्तत्त्वदर्शिना ॥

data.md: Being thus questioned, he answered to his preceptor, “Sir, after giving you all I get by begging, I go again to beg to support myself.”

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः प्रत्युवाच । नैषा न्याय्या गुरुवृत्तिः । अन्येषामपि वृत्त्युपरोधं करोष्येवं वर्तमानः । लुब्धोऽसीति ॥
data.md: The preceptor, said “This is not the way you should obey your preceptor. You diminish the support of others who live by begging. Having thus supported yourself you have showed that you are coveteous.

data.v: स तथेत्युक्त्वा गा अरक्षत् । रक्षित्वा च पुनरुपाध्यायगृहमागम्योपाध्यायस्याग्रतः स्थित्वा नमश्चक्रे ॥
data.md: Having assented to all his preceptor's words, he went away (again) to tend the kine Having done it, he stood before the preceptor and respectfully saluted him.

data.v: तमुपाध्यायस्तथापि पीवानमेव दृष्ट्वा पुनरुवाच । अहं ते सर्वं भैक्षं गृह्णामि न चान्यच्चरसि । पीवानसि । केन वृत्तिं कल्पयसीति ॥
data.md: The preceptor saw that he was still plump and said, "Upamanyu, my child, I take from you all that you get by begging. You do not also go out begging for the second time. How do you now manage to support yourself?”

data.v: स उपाध्यायं प्रत्युवाच । भो एतासां गवां पयसा वृत्तिं कल्पयामीति ॥
data.md: He answered to his preceptor, “I support myself by begging."

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः प्रत्युवाच । नैतन्न्याय्यं पय उपयोक्तुं भवतो मयाननुज्ञातमिति ॥
data.md: Upamanyu, thus questioned, replied, “Sir, I now support myself with the milk of these cows.” Hearing which the preceptor said, “It is not proper for you to drink the milk, since you were not addressed by me."

data.v: स तथेति प्रतिज्ञाय गा रक्षित्वा पुनरुपाध्यायगृहानेत्य गुरोरग्रतः स्थित्वा नमश्चक्रे ॥
data.md: He assented to his preceptor's words and went to tend the cattle. Having done it he stood before his preceptor and respectfully saluted him.

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः पीवानमेवापश्यत् । उवाच चैनम् । भैक्षं नाश्नासि न चान्यच्चरसि । पयो न पिबसि । पीवानसि । केन वृत्तिं कल्पयसीति ॥
data.md: The preceptor saw that he was still fat and he asked, “Upamanyu my child, you do not support yourself by alms, nor do you go begging for the second time, nor do you drink the milk of my cows, but you are still fat, how do you support yourself now?"

data.v: स एवमुक्त उपाध्यायं प्रत्युवाच । भोः फेनं पिबामि यमिमे वत्सा मातॄणां स्तनं पिबन्त उद्गिरन्तीति ॥
data.md: Thus questioned he said, “I now drink the froth that the calves throw out when they suck their mother's teats."

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः प्रत्युवाच । एते त्वदनुकम्पया गुणवन्तो वत्साः प्रभूततरं फेनमुद्गिरन्ति । तदेवमपि वत्सानां वृत्त्युपरोधं करोष्येवं वर्तमानः । फेनमपि भवान्न पातुमर्हतीति ॥
data.md: The preceptor replied, “The good calves, out of kindness towards you, throw out a large quantity of froth. You should not stand in the way of their full meal. Know, it is not proper for you to drink the froth.” Upamanyu assented to this and went to tend the cattle.

data.v: स तथेति प्रतिज्ञाय निराहारस्ता गा अरक्षत् । तथा प्रतिषिद्धो भैक्षं नाश्नाति न चान्यच्चरति । पयो न पिबति । फेनं नोपयुङ्क्ते ॥
स कदाचिदरण्ये क्षुधार्तोऽर्कपत्राण्यभक्षयत् ॥
स तैरर्कपत्रैर्भक्षितैः क्षारकटूष्णविपाकिभिश्चक्षुष्युपहतोऽन्धोऽभवत् । सोऽन्धोऽपि चङ्क्रम्यमाणः कूपेऽपतत् ॥
अथ तस्मिन्ननागच्छत्युपाध्यायः शिष्यानवोचत् । मयोपमन्युः सर्वतः प्रतिषिद्धः । स नियतं कुपितः । ततो नागच्छति चिरगतश्चेति ॥
स एवमुक्त्वा गत्वारण्यमुपमन्योराह्वानं चक्रे । भो उपमन्यो क्वासि । वत्सैहीति ॥
data.md: Having gone there, he cried, “O Aruni of Panchala, where are you? Come here, my child."

data.v: स तदाह्वानमुपाध्यायाच्छ्रुत्वा प्रत्युवाचोच्चैः । अयमस्मि भो उपाध्याय कूपे पतित इति ॥
data.md: Having heard the voice of his preceptor he replied, “I have fallen into this well.” The preceptor asked, “How have you fallen into this well?"

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः प्रत्युवाच । कथमसि कूपे पतित इति ॥
data.md: He answered to the preceptor, “I have become blind by eating the leaves of Arka tree and thus fallen into this well."

data.v: स तं प्रत्युवाच । अर्कपत्राणि भक्षयित्वान्धीभूतोऽस्मि । अतः कूपे पतित इति ॥
data.md: He answered to the preceptor, “I have become blind by eating the leaves of Arka tree and thus fallen into this well."

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः प्रत्युवाच । अश्विनौ स्तुहि । तौ त्वां चक्षुष्मन्तं करिष्यतो देवभिषजाविति ॥
data.md: On this the preceptor replied, “Worship the twin Ashvinis, the physicians of the celestials and they will restore you your sight.” Thus addressed, Upamanyu began to worship the twin Ashvinis by reciting the following words from the Rigveda.

data.v: स एवमुक्त उपाध्यायेन स्तोतुं प्रचक्रमे देवावश्विनौ वाग्भिरृग्भिः ॥
data.md: On this the preceptor replied, “Worship the twin Ashvinis, the physicians of the celestials and they will restore you your sight.” Thus addressed, Upamanyu began to worship the twin Ashvinis by reciting the following words from the Rigveda.

data.v: प्र पूर्वगौ पूर्वजौ चित्रभानू; गिरा वा शंसामि तपनावनन्तौ । दिव्यौ सुपर्णौ विरजौ विमाना;वधिक्षियन्तौ भुवनानि विश्वा ॥
data.md: You have existed before the creation, O you first-born beings; you are manifest in this wonderful universe of five elements. You are . infinite, you are the course of nature and intelligent Soul that pervades all. I desire to obtain you by the knowledge, derived from hearing and meditation, You are birds of beautiful feathers, that roost on the body which is likened to a tree. You are free from the three common attributes of all souls. You are beyond all comparison. You pervade the universe through its spirit in every created thing.

data.v: हिरण्मयौ शकुनी सांपरायौ; नासत्यदस्रौ सुनसौ वैजयन्तौ । शुक्रं वयन्तौ तरसा सुवेमा;वभि व्ययन्तावसितं विवस्वत् ॥
data.md: You are golden eagles. You are the essence in which all things disappear. You are free from error and you do not deteriorate. You are of beautiful beaks. which will not unjustly wound and which are ever victorious in all fights. Having created the sun, you weave the wonderful cloth of night and day by the black and white threads. You have established with as the cloth thus woven two courses of action; one regarding the Devas and the other regarding the Pitris.

data.v: ग्रस्तां सुपर्णस्य बलेन वर्तिका;ममुञ्चतामश्विनौ सौभगाय । तावत्सुवृत्तावनमन्त मायया; सत्तमा गा अरुणा उदावहन् ॥
data.md: You set free the bird of life, seized by Time representing the infinite soul, so that it may be delivered to great happiness. Those that are greatly ignorant on account of the delusion of their senses, think that you, who have no attributes of matter, have forms.

data.v: षष्टिश्च गावस्त्रिशताश्च धेनव; एकं वत्सं सुवते तं दुहन्ति । नानागोष्ठा विहिता एकदोहना;स्तावश्विनौ दुहतो घर्ममुक्थ्यम् ॥
data.md: Three hundred and sixty cows represented by three hundred and sixty days give birth to one calf which is year. This calf is the creator and destroyer of all. Those that search after truth, through following different routes, draw the milk of true knowledge with its help.

data.v: एकां नाभिं सप्तशता अराः श्रिताः; प्रधिष्वन्या विंशतिरर्पिता अराः । अनेमि चक्रं परिवर्ततेऽजरं; मायाश्विनौ समनक्ति चर्षणी ॥
data.md: The year is a navel of the wheel with seven hundred and twenty spokes, representing nights and days. The circumference of this wheel is without an end and is represented by twelve months. This wheel is full of delusion and does not know deterioration. It affects all creatures belonging to this or the other world. O Ashvinis, set this wheel in motion.

data.v: एकं चक्रं वर्तते द्वादशारं प्रधि;षण्णाभिमेकाक्षममृतस्य धारणम् । यस्मिन्देवा अधि विश्वे विषक्ता;स्तावश्विनौ मुञ्चतो मा विषीदतम् ॥
data.md: The wheel of time represented by the year has also a nave, the six seasons. It has twelve spokes represented by the twelve signs of the Zodiac. This wheel of Time displays the fruits of all beings' actions. The Presiding Deities of Time obey this wheel. Bound as I am to its bound, O Ashvinis, makes me free from this wheel of Time.

data.v: अश्विनाविन्द्रममृतं वृत्तभूयौ; तिरोधत्तामश्विनौ दासपत्नी । भित्त्वा गिरिमश्विनौ गामुदाचरन्तौ; तद्वृष्टमह्ना प्रथिता वलस्य ॥
data.md: O Ashvinis, you are this universe of five elements. You are the objects that are enjoyed in this and the next world. Raise me beyond the influence of the five elements. You are the supreme Brahma, but you move on earth in forms and enjoy those pleasures that the senses give.

data.v: युवां दिशो जनयथो दशाग्रे; समानं मूर्ध्नि रथया वियन्ति । तासां यातमृषयोऽनुप्रयान्ति; देवा मनुष्याः क्षितिमाचरन्ति ॥
data.md: You created ten points of the universe in the beginning of the creation. You have placed the sun and the moon above. The Rishis perform their Yajnas according to the course of the sun. The celestials and men also perform their Yajnas as settled for them and they enjoy the fruits of those acts.

data.v: युवां वर्णान्विकुरुथो विश्वरूपां;स्तेऽधिक्षियन्ति भुवनानि विश्वा । ते भानवोऽप्यनुसृताश्चरन्ति; देवा मनुष्याः क्षितिमाचरन्ति ॥
data.md: Mixing the ten colours, you have produced all the objects of form. The universe has sprung from these objects in which both the celestials and men and all creatures endued with life are engaged in their respective works.

data.v: तौ नासत्यावश्विनावामहे वां; स्रजं च यां बिभृथः पुष्करस्य । तौ नासत्यावमृतावृतावृधा;वृते देवास्तत्प्रपदेन सूते ॥
data.md: O Ashvinis, I worship you. I also worship the sky that is your handiwork. You are the ordainers of the fruits of all acts from which even the celestials are not free; you are, however, free from the fruits of your actions.

data.v: मुखेन गर्भं लभतां युवानौ; गतासुरेतत्प्रपदेन सूते । सद्यो जातो मातरमत्ति गर्भ;स्तावश्विनौ मुञ्चथो जीवसे गाः ॥
data.md: You are the parents of all. You as males and females swallow the food which subsequently develops into the vital-fluid and blood. The new-born baby sucks her mother's breast, it is you who take the shape of the babe. O Ashvinis, restore my sight and protect my life."

data.v: एवं तेनाभिष्टुतावश्विनावाजग्मतुः । आहतुश्चैनम् । प्रीतौ स्वः । एष तेऽपूपः । अशानैनमिति ॥
data.md: When Upamanyu thus adored the twin Ashvinis, they appeared and said. "We are pleased with your devotion. Here is a cake for you. Take it and eat it."

data.v: स एवमुक्तः प्रत्युवाच । नानृतमूचतुर्भवन्तौ । न त्वहमेतमपूपमुपयोक्तुमुत्सहे अनिवेद्य गुरव इति ॥
data.md: Thus addressed he replied, “O Ashvinis, your words never prove untrue. But I cannot take this cake without offering it to my preceptor.

data.v: ततस्तमश्विनावूचतुः । आवाभ्यां पुरस्ताद्भवत उपाध्यायेनैवमेवाभिष्टुताभ्यामपूपः प्रीताभ्यां दत्तः । उपयुक्तश्च स तेनानिवेद्य गुरवे । त्वमपि तथैव कुरुष्व यथा कृतमुपाध्यायेनेति ॥
data.md: The Ashvinis said-"Your preceptor also once invoked us, we gave him a cake and he took it without offering it to his teacher. Do what your preceptor did."

data.v: स एवमुक्तः पुनरेव प्रत्युवाचैतौ । प्रत्यनुनये भवन्तावश्विनौ । नोत्सहेऽहमनिवेद्योपाध्यायायोपयोक्तुमिति ॥
data.md: Thus addressed he said, "O Ashvinis, I ask your pardon. I cannot take this cake without offering it to my preceptor.

data.v: तमश्विनावाहतुः । प्रीतौ स्वस्तवानया गुरुवृत्त्या । उपाध्यायस्य ते कार्ष्णायसा दन्ताः । भवतो हिरण्मया भविष्यन्ति । चक्षुष्मांश्च भविष्यसि । श्रेयश्चावाप्स्यसीति ॥
data.md: The Ashvinis said, “We are pleased with your this devotion to your preceptor. Your teacher's teeth are of black iron, yours will be those of Gold. Your sight will be restored and you will possess good fortune."

data.v: स एवमुक्तोऽश्विभ्यां लब्धचक्षुरुपाध्यायसकाशमागम्योपाध्यायमभिवाद्याचचक्षे । स चास्य प्रीतिमानभूत् ॥
आह चैनम् । यथाश्विनावाहतुस्तथा त्वं श्रेयोऽवाप्स्यसीति । सर्वे च ते वेदाः प्रतिभास्यन्तीति ॥
data.md: And as you have obeyed my command, you shall obtain good fortune. All the Vedas will shine in you and so will all the Dharma Shastras."

data.v: एषा तस्यापि परीक्षोपमन्योः ॥
अथापरः शिष्यस्तस्यैवायोदस्य धौम्यस्य वेदो नाम ॥
data.md: Being thus blessed by his preceptor, Aruni went away to the country where his heart longed to go. The name of another AyudaDhaumya's disciples was Upamanyu.

data.v: तमुपाध्यायः संदिदेश । वत्स वेद इहास्यताम् । भवता मद्गृहे कंचित्कालं शुश्रूषमाणेन भवितव्यम् । श्रेयस्ते भविष्यतीति ॥
data.md: The other pupil of Ayuda Dhaumya was called Veda. One day his preceptor addressed him thus, “Veda, my child, remain in my house and serve your teacher. It will be to your profit."

data.v: स तथेत्युक्त्वा गुरुकुले दीर्घकालं गुरुशुश्रूषणपरोऽवसत् । गौरिव नित्यं गुरुषु धूर्षु नियुज्यमानः शीतोष्णक्षुत्तृष्णादुःखसहः सर्वत्राप्रतिकूलः ॥
data.md: Veda, having assented to it, remained long in the family of his preceptor, being always mindful to serve him. Like an ox under the burden of his owner, he bore heat and cold, hunger and thirst, without any complaint at all times; and many years thus passed before his preceptor was satisfied.

data.v: तस्य महता कालेन गुरुः परितोषं जगाम । तत्परितोषाच्च श्रेयः सर्वज्ञतां चावाप । एषा तस्यापि परीक्षा वेदस्य ॥
data.md: Veda obtained good fortune and universal knowledge as the result of his preceptor's satisfaction. This was his trial.

data.v: स उपाध्यायेनानुज्ञातः समावृत्तस्तस्माद्गुरुकुलवासाद्गृहाश्रमं प्रत्यपद्यत । तस्यापि स्वगृहे वसतस्त्रयः शिष्या बभूवुः ॥
data.md: Having received his preceptor's permission he left his house after the completion of living at his house and entered the domestic inode of life. When he was living in his house he got, three pupils. But he never asked them to perform any work or to serve him in any way. Having himself suffered much woe when living in the family of his preceptor, he did nor like to treat his pupils with severity

data.v: अथ कस्यचित्कालस्य वेदं ब्राह्मणं जनमेजयः पौष्यश्च क्षत्रियावुपेत्योपाध्यायं वरयां चक्रतुः ॥
data.md: Once on a time both the kings Janamejaya and Paushya came to his house and appointed him as their preceptor.

data.v: स कदाचिद्याज्यकार्येणाभिप्रस्थित उत्तङ्कं नाम शिष्यं नियोजयामास । भो उत्तङ्क यत्किंचिदस्मद्गृहे परिहीयते तदिच्छाम्यहमपरिहीणं भवता क्रियमाणमिति ॥
data.md: One day when he was going to depart on a sacrificial business, he employed one of his pupils, named Uttanka, to look after nis house and family. He said, “Uttanka, whatever should be required to be done in my house, let it be done by you without neglect." Having given him these instructions, Veda went away on his journey.

data.v: स एवं प्रतिसमादिश्योत्तङ्कं वेदः प्रवासं जगाम ॥

data.md: Uttanka, being always mindful of the service, as asked by his preceptor, lived in the family of his teacher While he was staying there, the females of his preceptor's house assembled near him and addressed him thus.

data.v: स वसंस्तत्रोपाध्यायस्त्रीभिः सहिताभिराहूयोक्तः । उपाध्यायिनी ते ऋतुमती । उपाध्यायश्च प्रोषितः । अस्या यथायमृतुर्वन्ध्यो न भवति तथा क्रियताम् । एतद्विषीदतीति ॥
data.md: "O Uttanka, the wife of your preceptor is in the state in which she might bear a child. Your preceptor is absent, therefore you are requested to stand in his place and do what is needful."

data.md: Uttanka, having been thus addressed, said to the women, “It is not proper for me to do it at the request of women. I have not been asked by my preceptor to do any thing which is not proper."

data.md: Some time after his preceptor returned from his journey. He heard all that had happened and was much pleased.

data.md: His preceptor then said, "My beloved Uttanka, you have repeatedly expressed your desire to bring something as an acknowledgement of the instructions you have received from me. Go to your mistress and ask her what you will bring for Dakshina.” Thus directed by his preceptor, Uttanka went to his teacher's wife and said, "Madam, I have received permission of my preceptor to depart and I am desirous to bring something that would be agreeable to you as my Dakshina for the instruction I have received, so that I may be free from my debt of gratitude."

data.v: स एवमुक्त उपाध्यायेनोपाध्यायिनीमपृच्छत् । भवत्युपाध्यायेनास्म्यनुज्ञातो गृहं गन्तुम् । तदिच्छामीष्टं ते गुर्वर्थमुपहृत्यानृणो गन्तुम् । तदाज्ञापयतु भवती । किमुपहरामि गुर्वर्थमिति ॥

data.v: सैवमुक्तोपाध्यायिन्युत्तङ्कं प्रत्युवाच । गच्छ पौष्यं राजानम् । भिक्षस्व तस्य क्षत्रियया पिनद्धे कुण्डले । ते आनयस्व । इतश्चतुर्थेऽहनि पुण्यकं भविता । ताभ्यामाबद्धाभ्यां ब्राह्मणान्परिवेष्टुमिच्छामि । शोभमाना यथा ताभ्यां कुण्डलाभ्यां तस्मिन्नहनि संपादयस्व । श्रेयो हि ते स्यात्क्षणं कुर्वत इति ॥

data.md: Thus ordered, Uttanka took his departure.' When he was passing along the road he met with an extraordinary large bull and a man of extraordinary large stature riding on it. The man addressed Uttanka thus.

data.v: स पुरुष उत्तङ्कमभ्यभाषत । उत्तङ्कैतत्पुरीषमस्य ऋषभस्य भक्षयस्वेति ॥
data.md: "O Uttanka, eat the dung of this bull." But Uttanka was not willing to eat it.

data.v: स एवमुक्तो नैच्छत् ॥
तमाह पुरुषो भूयः । भक्षयस्वोत्तङ्क । मा विचारय । उपाध्यायेनापि ते भक्षितं पूर्वमिति ॥
data.md: The man again said, "O Uttanka, eat it without hesitation. Your teacher ate it before."

data.v: स एवमुक्तो बाढमित्युक्त्वा तदा तदृषभस्य पुरीषं मूत्रं च भक्षयित्वोत्तङ्कः प्रतस्थे यत्र स क्षत्रियः पौष्यः ॥

data.md: “I have come to you and stand before you a petitioner.” King Paushya, returning his salutations said, "Sir, what shall I do for you?"

data.v: तमुवाचोत्तङ्कः । गुर्वर्थे कुण्डलाभ्यामर्थ्यागतोऽस्मीति ये ते क्षत्रियया पिनद्धे कुण्डले ते भवान्दातुमर्हतीति ॥
data.md: Uttanka replied, “I have come to beg from you your queen's ear-rings as a Dakshina to be given to my preceptor. You should give me those ear-rings."

data.v: तं पौष्यः प्रत्युवाच । प्रविश्यान्तःपुरं क्षत्रिया याच्यतामिति ॥
data.md: King Paushya said “Go into the innerapartment and ask it from the queen.” He went there, but could not see her.

data.v: स पौष्यं पुनरुवाच । न युक्तं भवता वयमनृतेनोपचरितुम् । न हि ते क्षत्रियान्तःपुरे संनिहिता । नैनां पश्यामीति ॥
data.md: He again said to the king, "You should not deceitfully treat me Your queen is not in the inner-apartment and I could not find her."

data.v: स एवमुक्तः पौष्यस्तं प्रत्युवाच । संप्रति भवानुच्छिष्टः । स्मर तावत् । न हि सा क्षत्रिया उच्छिष्टेनाशुचिना वा शक्या द्रष्टुम् । पतिव्रतात्वादेषा नाशुचेर्दर्शनमुपैतीति ॥

The queen is a chaste woman and therefore she cannot be seen by one who is defiled by the impurities of a repast. She does not appear before one who is so defiled."

data.md: Uttanka, thus addressed, thought for a while and then replied, “ Yes, it is so. As I was in a hurry, I performed my ablutions when I was walking." Paushya said, "This is a transgression. Ablutions cannot properly be performed standing or walking in a hurry.”

data.v: तं पौष्यः प्रत्युवाच । एतत्तदेवं हि । न गच्छतोपस्पृष्टं भवति न स्थितेनेति ॥
data.md: Paushya said, "I am not capable of revoking my curse. My anger is not appeased even now. But you do not know it.

He then without sound thrice sipped water which was free from scum and froth and which was not warm. He took only so much of it as to reach his stomach. He then wiped his face twice. He then touched his eyes, ears etc., with water. Having done all this he again went to the inner-apartment.

data.md: Uttanka said to her, “You should give me your ear-rings. I beg them from you as I wish to present them to my preceptor.” The queen, having been highly pleased with the conduct of Uttanka, thought that he was a very good man and he could not be refused. Therefore. she took off her ear-rings and handed them over to him. On giving them to Uttanka she said, “These ear-rings are very much sought after by Takshaka, the King of the Nagas. Therefore take them with the greatest care."

data.v: आह चैनम् । एते कुण्डले तक्षको नागराजः प्रार्थयति । अप्रमत्तो नेतुमर्हसीति ॥

data.md: Uttanka, being thus told, replied to the queen, "Madam, you need not be under any apprehension. Takshaka, the king of the Nagas, cannot overcome me."

data.md: “Sir, the food placed before you is cold and has really hair in it, having been prepared without sufficient care. Therefore, I pray you, kindly pardon me. Let me not become blind." Uttanka replied.

data.md: “What I say must happen. Having become blind, you may however regain your sight soon, Grant also that your curse on me may not take effect."

data.md: You can thus revenge your father's death. O king, You can thus do me a great favour.

data.v: कर्मणः पृथिवीपाल मम येन दुरात्मना । विघ्नः कृतो महाराज गुर्वर्थं चरतोऽनघ ॥
data.md: O king of the world, my business was obstructed on one occasion by that wretch when I was going (to get a present for my preceptor.)

data.v: एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु नृपतिस्तक्षकस्य चुकोप ह । उत्तङ्कवाक्यहविषा दीप्तोऽग्निर्हविषा यथा ॥
data.md: Sauti said : The king, having heard these words, got angry on Takshaka. Uttanka's speech inflamed him as ghee does the sacrificial fire.

data.v: अपृच्छच्च तदा राजा मन्त्रिणः स्वान्सुदुःखितः । उत्तङ्कस्यैव सांनिध्ये पितुः स्वर्गगतिं प्रति ॥
data.md: Even in the presence of Uttanka, he sorrowfully asked his ministers the particulars of his father's going to heaven (death).

data.v: तदैव हि स राजेन्द्रो दुःखशोकाप्लुतोऽभवत् । यदैव पितरं वृत्तमुत्तङ्कादशृणोत्तदा ॥
data.md: When he heard all the circumstances of his father's death from Uttanka, the king of kings was overcome with sorrow and pain.

data.v: लोमहर्षणपुत्र उग्रश्रवाः सूतः पौराणिको नैमिषारण्ये शौनकस्य कुलपतेर्द्वादशवार्षिके सत्रे ऋषीनभ्यागतानुपतस्थे ॥
data.md: Lomaharshana's son Ugrashrava Sauti, well-read in the Puranas, being present at the twelve years' sacrifice of Kulapati Shaunaka in the forest of Naimisha, stood before the Rishis in attendance.

data.v: पौराणिकः पुराणे कृतश्रमः स तान्कृताञ्जलिरुवाच । किं भवन्तः श्रोतुमिच्छन्ति । किमहं ब्रुवाणीति ॥
data.md: Having read the Puranas with great pains he was very learned in them. Now with joined hands he addressed them thus, "What, Reverend Sirs, do you wish to hear? What am I to relate?"

data.v: तमृषय ऊचुः । परमं लोमहर्षणे प्रक्ष्यामस्त्वां वक्ष्यसि च नः शुश्रूषतां कथायोगम् । तद्भगवांस्तु तावच्छौनकोऽग्निशरणमध्यास्ते ॥
data.md: The Rishis replied, "O son of Lomaharshana, we shall ask you and you will relate to us, who are anxious to hear, some excellent stories.

data.v: योऽसौ दिव्याः कथा वेद देवतासुरसंकथाः । मनुष्योरगगन्धर्वकथा वेद च सर्वशः ॥
data.md: He knows the divine stories relating to the Devas and Asuras. He also knows the stories relating to men, Nagas and Gandharvas.

data.v: स चाप्यस्मिन्मखे सौते विद्वान्कुलपतिर्द्विजः । दक्षो धृतव्रतो धीमाञ्शास्त्रे चारण्यके गुरुः ॥
data.md: O Sauti, that Kulapati Brahmana is the chief in this sacrifice; he is able, faithful to his vows, wise and a master of the Shastras and Aranyakas.

data.v: सत्यवादी शमपरस्तपस्वी नियतव्रतः । सर्वेषामेव नो मान्यः स तावत्प्रतिपाल्यताम् ॥
data.md: He is truthful, a lover of peace, a Rishi of hard austerities and an observer of the ordained penances. He is respected by all of us and we should, therefore, wait for him.

data.v: तस्मिन्नध्यासति गुरावासनं परमार्चितम् । ततो वक्ष्यसि यत्त्वां स प्रक्ष्यति द्विजसत्तमः ॥
data.md: When he will sit on the highly honoured seat for the preceptor, you will reply to what best of the twice born will ask you.

data.v: एवमस्तु गुरौ तस्मिन्नुपविष्टे महात्मनि । तेन पृष्टः कथाः पुण्या वक्ष्यामि विविधाश्रयाः ॥
data.md: Sauti said: So be it. When the noble Rishi will be seated, I shall relate sacred stories relating to variety of subjects as I shall be asked by him.

data.v: सोऽथ विप्रर्षभः कार्यं कृत्वा सर्वं यथाक्रमम् । देवान्वाग्भिः पितॄनद्भिस्तर्पयित्वाजगाम ह ॥
data.md: The best of Brahmanas (Shaunaka) after having performed all his Prayers to Devas and the Pitris by offering water, came back to the place of sacrifice where Sauti was seated before the assembly of Rishis of rigid vows.

data.v: यत्र ब्रह्मर्षयः सिद्धास्त आसीना यतव्रताः । यज्ञायतनमाश्रित्य सूतपुत्रपुरःसराः ॥
data.md: The best of Brahmanas (Shaunaka) after having performed all his Prayers to Devas and the Pitris by offering water, came back to the place of sacrifice where Sauti was seated before the assembly of Rishis of rigid vows.

data.v: ऋत्विक्ष्वथ सदस्येषु स वै गृहपतिस्ततः । उपविष्टेषूपविष्टः शौनकोऽथाब्रवीदिदम् ॥
data.md: When Shaunaka was seated in the midst of Ritviks and Sadasyas (members) who also had come to their places, Sauti spoke as follows.

data.v: पुराणमखिलं तात पिता तेऽधीतवान्पुरा । कच्चित्त्वमपि तत्सर्वमधीषे लोमहर्षणे ॥
data.md: Shaunaka said: Your father read the whole of the Puranas in the days of yore. O Son of Lomaharshana, have you also made them your study?

data.v: पुराणे हि कथा दिव्या आदिवंशाश्च धीमताम् । कथ्यन्ते ताः पुरास्माभिः श्रुताः पूर्वं पितुस्तव ॥
data.md: There are in the Puranas interesting stories and the history of the first generations of the wise men. We have heard them all recited by your father.

data.v: तत्र वंशमहं पूर्वं श्रोतुमिच्छामि भार्गवम् । कथयस्व कथामेतां कल्याः स्म श्रवणे तव ॥
data.md: I am desirous of hearing the history of the Bhrigu race. Tell us that history. We are all attention to listen to you.

data.v: यदधीतं पुरा सम्यग्द्विजश्रेष्ठ महात्मभिः । वैशंपायनविप्राद्यैस्तैश्चापि कथितं पुरा ॥
data.md: Sauti said : That which was formerly studied by the noble Brahmanas, which was studied and narrated by Vaishampayana and others.

data.v: यदधीतं च पित्रा मे सम्यक्चैव ततो मया । तत्तावच्छृणु यो देवैः सेन्द्रैः साग्निमरुद्गणैः । पूजितः प्रवरो वंशो भृगूणां भृगुनन्दन ॥
data.md: Which was also studied by my father, has been acquired by me. Hear with all attention, O descendant of the Bhrigu race, the history of your race, respected by Indra and all the celestials, all the Rishis and the Marutas. In this great race the great and blessed Rishi Bhrigu was born.

data.v: इमं वंशमहं ब्रह्मन्भार्गवं ते महामुने । निगदामि कथायुक्तं पुराणाश्रयसंयुतम् ॥
भृगोः सुदयितः पुत्रश्च्यवनो नाम भार्गवः । च्यवनस्यापि दायादः प्रमतिर्नाम धार्मिकः । प्रमतेरप्यभूत्पुत्रो घृताच्यां रुरुरित्युत ॥
data.md: Chyavana had a virtuous son, named Pramati. He had a son, named Ruru by Ghritachi.

data.v: रुरोरपि सुतो जज्ञे शुनको वेदपारगः । प्रमद्वरायां धर्मात्मा तव पूर्वपितामहात् ॥
data.md: Ruru had a son by his wife Pramadvara. O Shaunaka, he was your grandfather; he was very virtuous and greatly learned in the Vedas.

data.v: तपस्वी च यशस्वी च श्रुतवान्ब्रह्मवित्तमः । धर्मिष्ठः सत्यवादी च नियतो नियतेन्द्रियः ॥
data.md: He was devoted to asceticism, had great repute, was learned in the Shruti, truthful, virtuous, well-regulated in his meals and was the most eminent amongst the learned in the Vedas.

data.v: सूतपुत्र यथा तस्य भार्गवस्य महात्मनः । च्यवनत्वं परिख्यातं तन्ममाचक्ष्व पृच्छतः ॥
data.md: Shaunaka said : O Son of Suta, why was the illustrious son of Bhrigu named Chyavana? I ask you, tell me all about it.

data.v: भृगोः सुदयिता भार्या पुलोमेत्यभिविश्रुता । तस्यां गर्भः समभवद्भृगोर्वीर्यसमुद्भवः ॥
data.md: Sauti replied : Bhrigu had a very beloved wife, (named Puloma) who became quick with child by him.

data.v: तस्मिन्गर्भे संभृतेऽथ पुलोमायां भृगूद्वह । समये समशीलिन्यां धर्मपत्न्यां यशस्विनः ॥
data.md: When the virtuous and chaste Pauloma was in that condition, one day the greatly famous and virtuous Bhrigu, leaving her at home, went to perform his ablutions. And it was then that a Rakshasa, named Puloma, came to the Rishi's hermitage.

data.v: अभिषेकाय निष्क्रान्ते भृगौ धर्मभृतां वरे । आश्रमं तस्य रक्षोऽथ पुलोमाभ्याजगाम ह ॥
data.md: When the virtuous and chaste Pauloma was in that condition, one day the greatly famous and virtuous Bhrigu, leaving her at home, went to perform his ablutions. And it was then that a Rakshasa, named Puloma, came to the Rishi's hermitage.

data.v: तं प्रविश्याश्रमं दृष्ट्वा भृगोर्भार्यामनिन्दिताम् । हृच्छयेन समाविष्टो विचेताः समपद्यत ॥
data.md: He, having entered into the hermitage, saw the irreproachable wife of Bhrigu. Seeing her he was filled with lust and lost his reason.

data.v: अभ्यागतं तु तद्रक्षः पुलोमा चारुदर्शना । न्यमन्त्रयत वन्येन फलमूलादिना तदा ॥
data.md: Seeing that a guest had come, beautiful Puloma, entertained him with roots and fruits of the wood.

data.v: तां तु रक्षस्ततो ब्रह्मन्हृच्छयेनाभिपीडितम् । दृष्ट्वा हृष्टमभूत्तत्र जिहीर्षुस्तामनिन्दिताम् ॥
data.md: O Rishi, the Rakshasa, having seen her, burnt in lust. He was very much delighted and he determined to carry away the irreproachable lady.

data.v: अथाग्निशरणेऽपश्यज्ज्वलितं जातवेदसम् । तमपृच्छत्ततो रक्षः पावकं ज्वलितं तदा ॥
शंस मे कस्य भार्येयमग्ने पृष्ट ऋतेन वै । सत्यस्त्वमसि सत्यं मे वद पावक पृच्छते ॥
मया हीयं पूर्ववृता भार्यार्थे वरवर्णिनी । पश्चात्त्विमां पिता प्रादाद्भृगवेऽनृतकारिणे ॥
सेयं यदि वरारोहा भृगोर्भार्या रहोगता । तथा सत्यं समाख्याहि जिहीर्षाम्याश्रमादिमाम् ॥
मन्युर्हि हृदयं मेऽद्य प्रदहन्निव तिष्ठति । मत्पूर्वभार्यां यदिमां भृगुः प्राप सुमध्यमाम् ॥
data.md: As I have found her alone in the hermitage, I am determined to carry her away by force. My heart burns with rage when I think that Bhrigu has obtained this beautiful woman who was betrothed to me.

data.v: तद्रक्ष एवमामन्त्र्य ज्वलितं जातवेदसम् । शङ्कमानो भृगोर्भार्यां पुनः पुनरपृच्छत ॥
data.md: Thus did the Rakshasa ask the flaming fire again and again, whether the lady was Bhrigu's wife.

data.v: त्वमग्ने सर्वभूतानामन्तश्चरसि नित्यदा । साक्षिवत्पुण्यपापेषु सत्यं ब्रूहि कवे वचः ॥
data.md: “O Agni, you always dwell in every creature as the witness of their piety and impiety. Answer my question truthfully.

data.v: मत्पूर्वभार्यापहृता भृगुणानृतकारिणा । सेयं यदि तथा मे त्वं सत्यमाख्यातुमर्हसि ॥
data.md: Bhrigu has appropriated her who was chosen by me as my wife. Tell me truly therefore, whether she is not truly my wife by first choice.

data.v: श्रुत्वा त्वत्तो भृगोर्भार्यां हरिष्याम्यहमाश्रमात् । जातवेदः पश्यतस्ते वद सत्यां गिरं मम ॥
data.md: Hearing from you whether she is Bhrigu's wife or not, I shall carry her away from the hermitage even in your presence. Therefore, answer me truthfully."

data.v: तस्य तद्वचनं श्रुत्वा सप्तार्चिर्दुःखितो भृशम् । भीतोऽनृताच्च शापाच्च भृगोरित्यब्रवीच्छनैः ॥
data.md: Sauti said: Having heard his words, the seven flamed Deity felt himself very much in difficulty. He was afraid to tell an untruth and was equally afraid of Bhrigu's curse. He at last slowly said.

data.v: अग्नेरथ वचः श्रुत्वा तद्रक्षः प्रजहार ताम् । ब्रह्मन्वराहरूपेण मनोमारुतरंहसा ॥
data.md: Sauti said: O Brahman, having heard these words of Agni, the Rakshasa assumed the form of a boar and carried her away as fast as the wind or the mind.

data.v: ततः स गर्भो निवसन्कुक्षौ भृगुकुलोद्वह । रोषान्मातुश्च्युतः कुक्षेश्च्यवनस्तेन सोऽभवत् ॥
data.md: The child, of Bhrigu, who was in her womb, was very much enraged at this violence and he dropped down from his mother's womb, For this reason he got the name as Chyavana.

data.v: तं दृष्ट्वा मातुरुदराच्च्युतमादित्यवर्चसम् । तद्रक्षो भस्मसाद्भूतं पपात परिमुच्य ताम् ॥
data.md: On seeing that the child had dropped from her mother's womb as shinning as the sun, he quitted the grasp of the lady. But he fell down and was burnt to ashes.

data.v: सा तमादाय सुश्रोणी ससार भृगुनन्दनम् । च्यवनं भार्गवं ब्रह्मन्पुलोमा दुःखमूर्च्छिता ॥
data.md: O descendant of Bhrigu, the beautiful Puloma, heing afflicted with grief, took up her child Chyavana and walked away.

data.v: तां ददर्श स्वयं ब्रह्मा सर्वलोकपितामहः । रुदतीं बाष्पपूर्णाक्षीं भृगोर्भार्यामनिन्दिताम् । सान्त्वयामास भगवान्वधूं ब्रह्मा पितामहः ॥
data.md: The Grandfather of all beings, Brahma himself saw the faultless wife of Bhrigu weeping with eyes full of tears.

data.v: अश्रुबिन्दूद्भवा तस्याः प्रावर्तत महानदी । अनुवर्तती सृतिं तस्या भृगोः पत्न्या यशस्विनः ॥
तस्या मार्गं सृतवतीं दृष्ट्वा तु सरितं तदा । नाम तस्यास्तदा नद्याश्चक्रे लोकपितामहः । वधूसरेति भगवांश्च्यवनस्याश्रमं प्रति ॥
data.md: The river followed the foot-steps of the wife of the great Rishi Bhrigu; and the Grandfather of the worlds seeing, it follow the path of his son's wife, named it himself. He called it Vadhusara and it passed by the hermitage of Chyavana.

data.v: स एवं च्यवनो जज्ञे भृगोः पुत्रः प्रतापवान् । तं ददर्श पिता तत्र च्यवनं तां च भामिनीम् ॥
data.md: In this way was born Chyavana, the son of Bhrigu of great power. And Bhrigu saw his son (yavana aid his beautiful mother. He asked his wife Puloma in a rage.

data.v: स पुलोमां ततो भार्यां पप्रच्छ कुपितो भृगुः । केनासि रक्षसे तस्मै कथितेह जिहीर्षवे । न हि त्वां वेद तद्रक्षो मद्भार्यां चारुहासिनीम् ॥
data.md: Bhrigu said : Who made you known to the Rakshasa resolved to carry you away? O lady of captivating smiles, he could not (himself) know you to be my wife.

data.v: तत्त्वमाख्याहि तं ह्यद्य शप्तुमिच्छाम्यहं रुषा । बिभेति को न शापान्मे कस्य चायं व्यतिक्रमः ॥
data.md: Tell me who it was that told the Rakshasa of you, so that I may curse him from anger. Who is that one who is not afraid of my curse? By whom was this offence done?

data.v: अग्निना भगवंस्तस्मै रक्षसेऽहं निवेदिता । ततो मामनयद्रक्षः क्रोशन्तीं कुररीमिव ॥
data.md: Puloma said: O Lord, I was made known to the Rakshasa by Agni. He carried me away who was weeping like the Kurari.

data.v: साहं तव सुतस्यास्य तेजसा परिमोक्षिता । भस्मीभूतं च तद्रक्षो मामुत्सृज्य पपात वै ॥
data.md: I was rescued only by the extraordinary brightness of your son. The Rakshasa quitted his grasp and falling to the ground, was turned into ashes.

data.v: इति श्रुत्वा पुलोमाया भृगुः परममन्युमान् । शशापाग्निमभिक्रुद्धः सर्वभक्षो भविष्यसि ॥
data.md: Sauti said: Having heard this from Puloma Bhrigu became exceedingly angry and out of anger he cursed Agni, saying, “Be an all devouring (element).

data.v: शप्तस्तु भृगुणा वह्निः क्रुद्धो वाक्यमथाब्रवीत् । किमिदं साहसं ब्रह्मन्कृतवानसि सांप्रतम् ॥
data.md: Sauti said: Thus being cursed by Bhrigu. Agni said in anger, “What do you mean, Brahmana, by this rashness that you have shown towards me.”

data.v: धर्मे प्रयतमानस्य सत्यं च वदतः समम् । पृष्टो यदब्रुवं सत्यं व्यभिचारोऽत्र को मम ॥
data.md: What transgression is committed by me, who tried to do justice and to speak the truth impartially? Being asked, I told the truth.

data.md: Ruru said: O messenger of heaven, (tell me) what means have been provided beforehand by the deities. Tell me in full, so that I may comply with it. You should save me.

data.v: आयुषोऽर्धं प्रयच्छस्व कन्यायै भृगुनन्दन । एवमुत्थास्यति रुरो तव भार्या प्रमद्वरा ॥
data.md: The Devaduta said : O Descendant of Bhrigu, give up half of your own life to your bride and O Ruru, your Pramadvara will then rise from the ground.

data.v: आयुषोऽर्धं प्रयच्छामि कन्यायै खेचरोत्तम । शृङ्गाररूपाभरणा उत्तिष्ठतु मम प्रिया ॥
data.md: Ruru said: O best of heaven's messengers, 1 give up half of my life to my bride. Let my beloved one rise in the beautiful form decked with ornaments.

data.v: ततो गन्धर्वराजश्च देवदूतश्च सत्तमौ । धर्मराजमुपेत्येदं वचनं प्रत्यभाषताम् ॥
data.md: Sauti said: The king of the Gandharvas and the greatly qualified messenger of heaven, both went to the Deity Dharma and addressed him thus :

data.v: धर्मराजायुषोऽर्धेन रुरोर्भार्या प्रमद्वरा । समुत्तिष्ठतु कल्याणी मृतैव यदि मन्यसे ॥
data.md: "O king Dharma, if it please you, let the beautiful bride of Ruru, Pramadvara, who is dead, rise up endued with a half of Ruru's life.”

data.v: प्रमद्वरा रुरोर्भार्या देवदूत यदीच्छसि । उत्तिष्ठत्वायुषोऽर्धेन रुरोरेव समन्विता ॥
data.md: The Dharmaraja said : "O messenger of heaven, if it be your wish, let the bride of Ruru Pramadvara, rise up endued with a half of Ruru's life.

data.v: एवमुक्ते ततः कन्या सोदतिष्ठत्प्रमद्वरा । रुरोस्तस्यायुषोऽर्धेन सुप्तेव वरवर्णिनी ॥
data.md: Sauti said : When Dharma thus spoke, the beautiful Pramadvara, the betrothed bride of Ruru, rose up as from a slumber, with a half of Ruru's life.

data.v: एतद्दृष्टं भविष्ये हि रुरोरुत्तमतेजसः । आयुषोऽतिप्रवृद्धस्य भार्यार्थेऽर्धं ह्रसत्विति ॥
data.md: It was seen afterwards that the bestowal of a half of his own life to resuscitate his bride by Ruru of long life, led to a curtailment of his own life.

data.v: तत इष्टेऽहनि तयोः पितरौ चक्रतुर्मुदा । विवाहं तौ च रेमाते परस्परहितैषिणौ ॥
data.md: Thereupon their fathers gladly married them off with due rites and the couple passed their days devoted to each other.

data.v: स लब्ध्वा दुर्लभां भार्यां पद्मकिञ्जल्कसप्रभाम् । व्रतं चक्रे विनाशाय जिह्मगानां धृतव्रतः ॥
data.md: Thus having obtained a wife, difficult to be obtained, who was beautiful and bright as the filaments of the lotus, the Rishi of hard austerities (Ruru) made a vow to destroy the serpent race.

data.v: स दृष्ट्वा जिह्मगान्सर्वांस्तीव्रकोपसमन्वितः । अभिहन्ति यथासन्नं गृह्य प्रहरणं सदा ॥
data.md: Whenever he saw a snake, he was filled with great anger and he always killed it with a weapon.

data.v: स कदाचिद्वनं विप्रो रुरुरभ्यागमन्महत् । शयानं तत्र चापश्यड्डुण्डुभं वयसान्वितम् ॥
data.md: One day, the Brahmana, Ruru entered into a very large forest. He saw an old Dundubha snake lying on the ground.

data.v: तत उद्यम्य दण्डं स कालदण्डोपमं तदा । अभ्यघ्नद्रुषितो विप्रस्तमुवाचाथ डुण्डुभः ॥
data.md: Thereupon with the intention of killing it, Ruru raised his staff in anger, A staff like the staff of Death. The Dundubha then said to the angry Brahmana.

data.v: नापराध्यामि ते किंचिदहमद्य तपोधन । संरम्भात्तत्किमर्थं मामभिहंसि रुषान्वितः ॥
data.md: "O Rishi, I have done you no harm. Why should you kill me in anger?"

data.v: मम प्राणसमा भार्या दष्टासीद्भुजगेन ह । तत्र मे समयो घोर आत्मनोरग वै कृतः ॥
data.md: Ruru said : My wife, who was as dear to me as my life, was bitten by a snake; on which I took, O snake, a fearful vow;

data.v: हन्यां सदैव भुजगं यं यं पश्येयमित्युत । ततोऽहं त्वां जिघांसामि जीवितेन विमोक्ष्यसे ॥
data.md: Namely that I would kill every snake that I might meet with. Therefore I shall strike you and you shall be deprived of your life.

data.v: अन्ये ते भुजगा विप्र ये दशन्तीह मानवान् । डुण्डुभानहिगन्धेन न त्वं हिंसितुमर्हसि ॥
data.md: The Dundubha said: O Brahmana, there are other snakes which bite man. The Dundubhas are only snakes in name. Therefore, you should not kill the Dundubhas.

data.v: एकानर्थान्पृथगर्थानेकदुःखान्पृथक्सुखान् । डुण्डुभान्धर्मविद्भूत्वा न त्वं हिंसितुमर्हसि ॥
data.md: Subject to the same calamity but not sharing the same good fortune, being same in woe, but different in joy, you should not kill the Dundubhas, being a knower of right and wrong.

data.v: इति श्रुत्वा वचस्तस्य भुजगस्य रुरुस्तदा । नावधीद्भयसंविग्न ऋषिं मत्वाथ डुण्डुभम् ॥
data.md: Sauti said: Hearing those words of the snake and seeing that the snake was really of the Dundubha kind and that it was terribly frightened. Ruru did not kill it, thinking that it is a Rishi.

data.v: उवाच चैनं भगवान्रुरुः संशमयन्निव । कामया भुजग ब्रूहि कोऽसीमां विक्रियां गतः ॥
data.md: Then Ruru, the possessor of six attributes, cheering up the snake, said to it, “Who are you, tell me, O snake, that have been thus metamorphosed?”

data.v: अहं पुरा रुरो नाम्ना ऋषिरासं सहस्रपात् । सोऽहं शापेन विप्रस्य भुजगत्वमुपागतः ॥
data.md: The Dundubha said: O Ruru, I was formerly a Rishi, named Shahasrapat. It is by the curse of a Brahmana that I have become a snake.

data.v: किमर्थं शप्तवान्क्रुद्धो द्विजस्त्वां भुजगोत्तम । कियन्तं चैव कालं ते वपुरेतद्भविष्यति ॥
data.md: Ruru said : O best of snakes, why were you cursed by an angry Brahmana? And how long will your this body continue?

data.v: सखा बभूव मे पूर्वं खगमो नाम वै द्विजः । भृशं संशितवाक्तात तपोबलसमन्वितः ॥
data.md: The Dundubha said : In time gone by, I had a friend, a Brahmana, by name Khagama. He was truthful and possessed spiritual powers by penances.

data.v: स मया क्रीडता बाल्ये कृत्वा तार्णमथोरगम् । अग्निहोत्रे प्रसक्तः सन्भीषितः प्रमुमोह वै ॥
data.md: When he was engaged in Agnihotra, out of boyish frivolity, I made a snake of the blades of grass and tried to frighten him. He fainted away (when he saw this mock snake).

data.v: लब्ध्वा च स पुनः संज्ञां मामुवाच तपोधनः । निर्दहन्निव कोपेन सत्यवाक्संशितव्रतः ॥
data.md: Recovering his senses, that truthful and penance-performing Rishi exclaimed to me in anger.

data.v: यथावीर्यस्त्वया सर्पः कृतोऽयं मद्बिभीषया । तथावीर्यो भुजंगस्त्वं मम कोपाद्भविष्यसि ॥
data.md: "As you made a powerful mock snake to frighten me, you will yourself turn into a venomless serpent by my curse."

data.v: तस्याहं तपसो वीर्यं जानमानस्तपोधन । भृशमुद्विग्नहृदयस्तमवोचं वनौकसम् ॥
data.md: O Rishi, I was well aware of the power of penances that he possessed. Therefore, with an agitated heart, I addressed him thus,

data.v: प्रयतः संभ्रमाच्चैव प्राञ्जलिः प्रणतः स्थितः । सखेति हसतेदं ते नर्मार्थं वै कृतं मया ॥
data.md: Bending low and joining both hands, "As I am your friend, I have done this only as a joke to make you laugh.

data.v: क्षन्तुमर्हसि मे ब्रह्मञ्शापोऽयं विनिवर्त्यताम् । सोऽथ मामब्रवीद्दृष्ट्वा भृशमुद्विग्नचेतसम् ॥
data.md: You should, O Brahmana, pardon me and revoke your curse." Seeing me very much distressed, the ascetic moved and breathing hot and hard, he said, What I have said must happen.

data.v: मुहुरुष्णं विनिःश्वस्य सुसंभ्रान्तस्तपोधनः । नानृतं वै मया प्रोक्तं भवितेदं कथंचन ॥
data.md: You should, O Brahmana, pardon me and revoke your curse." Seeing me very much distressed, the ascetic moved and breathing hot and hard, he said, What I have said must happen.

data.v: यत्तु वक्ष्यामि ते वाक्यं शृणु तन्मे धृतव्रत । श्रुत्वा च हृदि ते वाक्यमिदमस्तु तपोधन ॥
data.md: O ascetic, listen to what I say and hearing it, O pious man, always keep it to your heart.

data.v: उत्पत्स्यति रुरुर्नाम प्रमतेरात्मजः शुचिः । तं दृष्ट्वा शापमोक्षस्ते भविता नचिरादिव ॥
data.md: When Ruru the holy, the son of Pramati will appear, you will be immediately relieved of the curse on seeing him.”

data.v: स त्वं रुरुरिति ख्यातः प्रमतेरात्मजः शुचिः । स्वरूपं प्रतिलभ्याहमद्य वक्ष्यामि ते हितम् ॥
data.md: You are the very Ruru, the son of Pramati. Now regaining my natural form I shall speak something for your benefit.

data.v: अहिंसा परमो धर्मः सर्वप्राणभृतां स्मृतः । तस्मात्प्राणभृतः सर्वान्न हिंस्याद्ब्राह्मणः क्वचित् ॥
data.md: Therefore, a Brahmana should never hurt any creature. The injunction of the Shruti is that a Brahmana should always be mild.

data.v: ब्राह्मणः सौम्य एवेह जायतेति परा श्रुतिः । वेदवेदाङ्गवित्तात सर्वभूताभयप्रदः ॥
अहिंसा सत्यवचनं क्षमा चेति विनिश्चितम् । ब्राह्मणस्य परो धर्मो वेदानां धरणादपि ॥
क्षत्रियस्य तु यो धर्मः स नेहेष्यति वै तव । दण्डधारणमुग्रत्वं प्रजानां परिपालनम् ॥
तदिदं क्षत्रियस्यासीत्कर्म वै शृणु मे रुरो । जनमेजयस्य धर्मात्मन्सर्पाणां हिंसनं पुरा ॥
परित्राणं च भीतानां सर्पाणां ब्राह्मणादपि । तपोवीर्यबलोपेताद्वेदवेदाङ्गपारगात् । आस्तीकाद्द्विजमुख्याद्वै सर्पसत्रे द्विजोत्तम ॥
data.md: It was by Astika learned in the Vedas and the Vedangas and mighty in spiritual power.

data.v: कथं हिंसितवान्सर्पान्क्षत्रियो जनमेजयः । सर्पा वा हिंसितास्तात किमर्थं द्विजसत्तम ॥
data.md: Ruru said: O best of the twice-born, why did king Janamejaya become the destroyer of the snakes and how did he destroy them?

data.v: किमर्थं मोक्षिताश्चैव पन्नगास्तेन शंस मे । आस्तीकेन तदाचक्ष्व श्रोतुमिच्छाम्यशेषतः ॥
data.md: Why were they saved by wise Astika, the best of Brahmanas? I am desirous of hearing all this.

data.v: श्रोष्यसि त्वं रुरो सर्वमास्तीकचरितं महत् । ब्राह्मणानां कथयतामित्युक्त्वान्तरधीयत ॥
data.md: Rishi said: O Ruru, you will hear the important history of Astika from the Brahmanas. Saying this he disappeared.

data.v: रुरुश्चापि वनं सर्वं पर्यधावत्समन्ततः । तमृषिं द्रष्टुमन्विच्छन्संश्रान्तो न्यपतद्भुवि ॥
data.md: Sauti said: Ruru rushed in search of the Rishi, but he did not find him in all the forest. Finding him not, he sat down on the ground, much fatigued.

data.v: लब्धसंज्ञो रुरुश्चायात्तच्चाचख्यौ पितुस्तदा । पिता चास्य तदाख्यानं पृष्टः सर्वं न्यवेदयत् ॥
data.md: Regaining his senses, he came home and asked his father (to relate the history) and his father related to him the story. End of Pau loma Parva

data.v: किमर्थं राजशार्दूलः स राजा जनमेजयः । सर्पसत्रेण सर्पाणां गतोऽन्तं तद्वदस्व मे ॥
data.md: Shaunaka said: son was Why did that best of kings, king Janamejaya, resolve to destroy the snakes in a Snake-sacrifice?

data.v: आस्तीकश्च द्विजश्रेष्ठः किमर्थं जपतां वरः । मोक्षयामास भुजगान्दीप्तात्तस्माद्धुताशनात् ॥
कस्य पुत्रः स राजासीत्सर्पसत्रं य आहरत् । स च द्विजातिप्रवरः कस्य पुत्रो वदस्व मे ॥
data.md: Whose the monarch who performed the Snake-sacrifice? Whose son was that best of the twice-born, (who saved the snakes)? Tell us this.

data.v: महदाख्यानमास्तीकं यत्रैतत्प्रोच्यते द्विज । सर्वमेतदशेषेण शृणु मे वदतां वर ॥
data.md: Sauti said: O best of speakers, the story of Astika is very long, I shall relate it in full. O Listen.

data.v: श्रोतुमिच्छाम्यशेषेण कथामेतां मनोरमाम् । आस्तीकस्य पुराणस्य ब्राह्मणस्य यशस्विनः ॥
data.md: Shaunaka said : I am desirous of hearing in detail the interesting story of Astika, the illustrious Brahmana.

data.v: इतिहासमिमं वृद्धाः पुराणं परिचक्षते । कृष्णद्वैपायनप्रोक्तं नैमिषारण्यवासिनः ॥
data.md: Sauti said: m The Brahmanas call this history, recited by Krishna Dvaipayana, a Purana, to the dwellers of Naimisharanya.

data.v: पूर्वं प्रचोदितः सूतः पिता मे लोमहर्षणः । शिष्यो व्यासस्य मेधावी ब्राह्मणैरिदमुक्तवान् ॥
data.md: It was formerly narrated by my learned father Lomaharshana, the disciple of Vyasa, as requested by the Brahmanas.

data.v: तस्मादहमुपश्रुत्य प्रवक्ष्यामि यथातथम् । इदमास्तीकमाख्यानं तुभ्यं शौनक पृच्छते ॥
data.md: I was present at the time, O Shaunaka, As you ask me, I shall recite it exactly as I heard it.

data.v: आस्तीकस्य पिता ह्यासीत्प्रजापतिसमः प्रभुः । ब्रह्मचारी यताहारस्तपस्युग्रे रतः सदा ॥
data.md: (Listen) to this all sin-destroying history. Astika's father was as powerful as the Prajapati.

data.v: जरत्कारुरिति ख्यात ऊर्ध्वरेता महानृषिः । यायावराणां धर्मज्ञः प्रवरः संशितव्रतः ॥
अटमानः कदाचित्स स्वान्ददर्श पितामहान् । लम्बमानान्महागर्ते पादैरूर्ध्वैरधोमुखान् ॥
तानब्रवीत्स दृष्ट्वैव जरत्कारुः पितामहान् । के भवन्तोऽवलम्बन्ते गर्तेऽस्मिन्वा अधोमुखाः ॥
वीरणस्तम्बके लग्नाः सर्वतः परिभक्षिते । मूषकेन निगूढेन गर्तेऽस्मिन्नित्यवासिना ॥
data.md: “Who are you thus hanging in the hole, your heads downward, by a rope of the Virana fibre which has been eaten by the rats that live secretly near this hole?"

data.v: यायावरा नाम वयमृषयः संशितव्रताः । संतानप्रक्षयाद्ब्रह्मन्नधो गच्छाम मेदिनीम् ॥
data.md: The Ancestors said : We are Rishis of austere penances, called Yayavaras. We are sinking down into the earth for want of an offspring.

data.v: अस्माकं संततिस्त्वेको जरत्कारुरिति श्रुतः । मन्दभाग्योऽल्पभाग्यानां तप एव समास्थितः ॥
data.md: We have a son, named Jaratkaru. Unfortunate we are, that wretch has adopted asceticism.

data.v: न स पुत्राञ्जनयितुं दारान्मूढश्चिकीर्षति । तेन लम्बामहे गर्ते संतानप्रक्षयादिह ॥
data.md: And therefore that fool does not think of marriage to raise up offspring. It is for this reason, namely for the want of offspring that we are thus suspended in the hole.

data.v: अनाथास्तेन नाथेन यथा दुष्कृतिनस्तथा । कस्त्वं बन्धुरिवास्माकमनुशोचसि सत्तम ॥
data.md: Having means, we are like sinners who have no means. O excellent man, who are you that are sorrowing for us like a friend?

data.v: तस्य पृष्ठमुपारुह्य बहुरत्नाचितं शुभम् । अनन्तकल्पमुद्विद्धं सुराः सर्वे महौजसः ॥
data.md: It stands high for infinite ages. Once did the celestials sit on its golden summit and held a conclave.

data.v: ते मन्त्रयितुमारब्धास्तत्रासीना दिवौकसः । अमृतार्थे समागम्य तपोनियमसंस्थिताः ॥
data.md: They, who had practised penances and observed vows, came in quest of the Ambrosia. They consulted together about the possession of the Ambrosia and seeing them in this mood Narayana addressed Brahma saying;

data.v: तत्र नारायणो देवो ब्रह्माणमिदमब्रवीत् । चिन्तयत्सु सुरेष्वेवं मन्त्रयत्सु च सर्वशः ॥
data.md: They, who had practised penances and observed vows, came in quest of the Ambrosia. They consulted together about the possession of the Ambrosia and seeing them in this mood Narayana addressed Brahma saying;

data.v: देवैरसुरसंघैश्च मथ्यतां कलशोदधिः । भविष्यत्यमृतं तत्र मथ्यमाने महोदधौ ॥
data.md: "Churn the ocean with both the Devas and the Asuras. By doing so, the Ambrosia and all drugs and gems will be obtained. O celestials, churn the ocean and you will get the Ambrosia.

data.v: सर्वौषधीः समावाप्य सर्वरत्नानि चैव हि । मन्थध्वमुदधिं देवा वेत्स्यध्वममृतं ततः ॥
data.md: "Churn the ocean with both the Devas and the Asuras. By doing so, the Ambrosia and all drugs and gems will be obtained. O celestials, churn the ocean and you will get the Ambrosia.

data.v: ततोऽभ्रशिखराकारैर्गिरिशृङ्गैरलंकृतम् । मन्दरं पर्वतवरं लताजालसमावृतम् ॥
data.md: Sauti said: There is a mountain called Mandara with peaks like the clouds. It is the best of mountains and adorned with innumerable creepers.

data.v: नानाविहगसंघुष्टं नानादंष्ट्रिसमाकुलम् । किंनरैरप्सरोभिश्च देवैरपि च सेवितम् ॥
data.md: On it do many birds pour forth their melody and may beasts of prey roam about; it is frequented by the Kinnaras, Apsaras and। celestials.

data.v: एकादश सहस्राणि योजनानां समुच्छ्रितम् । अधो भूमेः सहस्रेषु तावत्स्वेव प्रतिष्ठितम् ॥
data.md: It rises eleven thousand Yojanas upwards and descends eleven thousand Yojanas downwards.

data.v: तमुद्धर्तुं न शक्ता वै सर्वे देवगणास्तदा । विष्णुमासीनमभ्येत्य ब्रह्माणं चेदमब्रुवन् ॥
data.md: The celestials, having failed to uproot it, came to Vishnu and Brahma who were sitting together and said to them.

data.v: भवन्तावत्र कुरुतां बुद्धिं नैःश्रेयसीं पराम् । मन्दरोद्धरणे यत्नः क्रियतां च हिताय नः ॥
data.md: "Devise some means you yourselves. Do try to uproot Mandara for our good.”

data.v: तथेति चाब्रवीद्विष्णुर्ब्रह्मणा सह भार्गव । ततोऽनन्तः समुत्थाय ब्रह्मणा परिचोदितः । नारायणेन चाप्युक्तस्तस्मिन्कर्मणि वीर्यवान् ॥
data.md: Being directed by both Brahma and Narayana to do it, the mighty Ananta uprooted the mountain with all the woods and the denizens of woods that were on it.

data.v: अथ पर्वतराजानं तमनन्तो महाबलः । उज्जहार बलाद्ब्रह्मन्सवनं सवनौकसम् ॥
data.md: Being directed by both Brahma and Narayana to do it, the mighty Ananta uprooted the mountain with all the woods and the denizens of woods that were on it.

data.v: ततस्तेन सुराः सार्धं समुद्रमुपतस्थिरे । तमूचुरमृतार्थाय निर्मथिष्यामहे जलम् ॥
data.md: Then came all the celestial with Ananta to the shores of the ocean, Addressing it they said, “O Ocean, we have come to churn you for the Ambrosia.

data.v: अपांपतिरथोवाच ममाप्यंशो भवेत्ततः । सोढास्मि विपुलं मर्दं मन्दरभ्रमणादिति ॥
data.md: The ocean replied, “Be it so, as I shall get a share of it. I am quite able to bear the great agitation arising out of the churning of my water by Mandara.

data.v: ऊचुश्च कूर्मराजानमकूपारं सुरासुराः । गिरेरधिष्ठानमस्य भवान्भवितुमर्हति ॥
data.md: The Devas and the Danavas then went to the Tortoise king and said, “You will have to support the mountain on your back.”

data.v: कूर्मेण तु तथेत्युक्त्वा पृष्ठमस्य समर्पितम् । तस्य शैलस्य चाग्रं वै यन्त्रेणेन्द्रोऽभ्यपीडयत् ॥
data.md: The Tortoise king having agreed, Indra pressed that mountain on its back by means of his thunderbolt.

data.v: मन्थानं मन्दरं कृत्वा तथा नेत्रं च वासुकिम् । देवा मथितुमारब्धाः समुद्रं निधिमम्भसाम् । अमृतार्थिनस्ततो ब्रह्मन्सहिता दैत्यदानवाः ॥
data.md: The Devas and the Danavas having made Mandara the churning staff and Vasuki the rope. O Brahmana, in days of yore, began to churn the ocean for the Ambrosia. The Asuras held him by the head and the Devas by the tail.

data.v: एकमन्तमुपाश्लिष्टा नागराज्ञो महासुराः । विबुधाः सहिताः सर्वे यतः पुच्छं ततः स्थिताः ॥
data.md: The Devas and the Danavas having made Mandara the churning staff and Vasuki the rope. O Brahmana, in days of yore, began to churn the ocean for the Ambrosia. The Asuras held him by the head and the Devas by the tail.

data.v: अनन्तो भगवान्देवो यतो नारायणस्ततः । शिर उद्यम्य नागस्य पुनः पुनरवाक्षिपत् ॥
data.md: And Ananta, who was a manifested form of Narayana, again and again raised and lowered the hood of the Naga.

data.v: वासुकेरथ नागस्य सहसाक्षिप्यतः सुरैः । सधूमाः सार्चिषो वाता निष्पेतुरसकृन्मुखात् ॥
data.md: On account of the great agitation, received at the hands of the celestials, black vapours with flames issued from the mouth of the Naga Vasuki.

data.v: ते धूमसंघाः संभूता मेघसंघाः सविद्युतः । अभ्यवर्षन्सुरगणाञ्श्रमसंतापकर्शितान् ॥
data.md: From these vapours were created clouds with lightning; and they poured showers on the tired celestials who were thus refreshed.

data.v: तस्माच्च गिरिकूटाग्रात्प्रच्युताः पुष्पवृष्टयः । सुरासुरगणान्माल्यैः सर्वतः समवाकिरन् ॥
data.md: The flowers that fell from the trees on the mountain-sides on the Devas and the Danavas also refreshed them.

data.v: बभूवात्र महाघोषो महामेघरवोपमः । उदधेर्मथ्यमानस्य मन्दरेण सुरासुरैः ॥
data.md: There rose from Mandara being dragged by the Devas and the Danavas, a terrible roar like the roar of the clouds (at the Universal dissolution).

data.v: तत्र नानाजलचरा विनिष्पिष्टा महाद्रिणा । विलयं समुपाजग्मुः शतशो लवणाम्भसि ॥
data.md: Various aquatic animals were crushed by the great mountain and gave up their lives in the salt sea.

data.v: वारुणानि च भूतानि विविधानि महीधरः । पातालतलवासीनि विलयं समुपानयत् ॥
data.md: Many denizens of the lower region and those of the land of Varuna were killed by the mountain.

data.v: तस्मिंश्च भ्राम्यमाणेऽद्रौ संघृष्यन्तः परस्परम् । न्यपतन्पतगोपेताः पर्वताग्रान्महाद्रुमाः ॥
data.md: From the whirling Mandara large trees, being struck at one another, were torn from their roots and fell into the ocean with all the birds (that roosted on their branches).

data.v: तेषां संघर्षजश्चाग्निरर्चिर्भिः प्रज्वलन्मुहुः । विद्युद्भिरिव नीलाभ्रमावृणोन्मन्दरं गिरिम् ॥
data.md: And great fires were produced from the mutual friction of the trees that frequently blazed up and the Mandara mountain looked like black clouds charged with lightning,

data.v: ददाह कुञ्जरांश्चैव सिंहांश्चैव विनिःसृतान् । विगतासूनि सर्वाणि सत्त्वानि विविधानि च ॥
data.md: It burnt the lions, elephants and other various creatures that were on the mountain and killed them (on the spot).

data.v: तमग्निममरश्रेष्ठः प्रदहन्तं ततस्ततः । वारिणा मेघजेनेन्द्रः शमयामास सर्वतः ॥
data.md: Then the best of the celestials, Indra began to extinguish the blazing fire by pouring heavy showers.

data.v: ततो नानाविधास्तत्र सुस्रुवुः सागराम्भसि । महाद्रुमाणां निर्यासा बहवश्चौषधीरसाः ॥
data.md: Then the gums of various great trees and juices from herbs mingled with the waters of the ocean.

data.v: तेषाममृतवीर्याणां रसानां पयसैव च । अमरत्वं सुरा जग्मुः काञ्चनस्य च निःस्रवात् ॥
data.md: The celestials became immortal by drinking the water mixed with the liquid extract of gold and those gums which had the quality of the Ambrosia.

data.v: अथ तस्य समुद्रस्य तज्जातमुदकं पयः । रसोत्तमैर्विमिश्रं च ततः क्षीरादभूद्घृतम् ॥
data.md: The milky water of the churned ocean by degrees produced clarified butter by virtue of those gums and juices.

data.v: ततो ब्रह्माणमासीनं देवा वरदमब्रुवन् । श्रान्ताः स्म सुभृशं ब्रह्मन्नोद्भवत्यमृतं च तत् ॥
data.md: Thereupon the Devas came to the boongranting God who was comfortably seated on his seat and said, “O Brahman, we are spent out but the Ambrosia has not yet arisen."

data.v: ऋते नारायणं देवं दैत्या नागोत्तमास्तथा । चिरारब्धमिदं चापि सागरस्यापि मन्थनम् ॥
data.md: Except Narayana, both the Devas and the Danavas have no strength to churn the ocean (any longer).

data.v: ततो नारायणं देवं ब्रह्मा वचनमब्रवीत् । विधत्स्वैषां बलं विष्णो भवानत्र परायणम् ॥
data.md: Then did Brahma say to Narayana, “Kindly give the celestials strength to churn the Ocean again with Mandara mountain, O Vishnu you are our refuge."

data.v: बलं ददामि सर्वेषां कर्मैतद्ये समास्थिताः । क्षोभ्यतां कलशः सर्वैर्मन्दरः परिवर्त्यताम् ॥
data.md: Narayana said : I grant all necessary strength for all those who are engaged in this action. Go, insert the mountain and churn the Ocean.

data.v: नारायणवचः श्रुत्वा बलिनस्ते महोदधेः । तत्पयः सहिता भूयश्चक्रिरे भृशमाकुलम् ॥
data.md: Thus hearing the words of Narayana and being re-equipped with fresh strength the celestial recommenced churning of the waters.

data.v: ततः शतसहस्रांशुः समान इव सागरात् । प्रसन्नभाः समुत्पन्नः सोमः शीतांशुरुज्ज्वलः ॥
data.md: Then from churning the ocean rose the amiable and brilliant Moon of thousand rays.

data.v: श्रीरनन्तरमुत्पन्ना घृतात्पाण्डुरवासिनी । सुरा देवी समुत्पन्ना तुरगः पाण्डुरस्तथा ॥
data.md: Then rose from that ghee, the whiteclothed Lakshmi; then Sura Devi (Wine) then the great white steed.

data.v: कौस्तुभश्च मणिर्दिव्य उत्पन्नोऽमृतसंभवः । मरीचिविकचः श्रीमान्नारायणउरोगतः ॥
data.md: Then from the ghee rose the celestial gem Kaustubha, the splendid by rays, which adorns the breast of Narayana. Then rose, O Brahmana, Parijata tree and Surabhi, all giver of everything.

data.v: श्रीः सुरा चैव सोमश्च तुरगश्च मनोजवः । यतो देवास्ततो जग्मुरादित्यपथमाश्रिताः ॥
data.md: Lakshmi, Wine, Moon, Horse (Uchchaishrava) which is fleet as the mind, all directed by Aditya went to the place where the celestials were.

data.v: धन्वन्तरिस्ततो देवो वपुष्मानुदतिष्ठत । श्वेतं कमण्डलुं बिभ्रदमृतं यत्र तिष्ठति ॥
data.md: Then rose the divine Dhanvantari with a white vessel in his hand and there in that vessel) was the Ambrosia.

data.v: एतदत्यद्भुतं दृष्ट्वा दानवानां समुत्थितः । अमृतार्थे महान्नादो ममेदमिति जल्पताम् ॥
data.md: Seeing this wonderful phenomenon, the Danavas raised a a great uproar for the Ambrosia, saying “It is mine."

data.v: ततो नारायणो मायामास्थितो मोहिनीं प्रभुः । स्त्रीरूपमद्भुतं कृत्वा दानवानभिसंश्रितः ॥
data.md: Thereupon Narayana assumed a form of a ravishing beauty by the aid of Maya and he began a flirtation with the Danavas in the form of a female.

data.v: ततस्तदमृतं तस्यै ददुस्ते मूढचेतसः । स्त्रियै दानवदैतेयाः सर्वे तद्गतमानसाः ॥
data.md: The foolish Danavas and Daityas becoming fully, enamoured of her, placed the Ambrosia in her hands.

data.v: अथावरणमुख्यानि नानाप्रहरणानि च । प्रगृह्याभ्यद्रवन्देवान्सहिता दैत्यदानवाः ॥
data.md: Sauti said : Then the Daityas and Danavas, in best armours and with various weapons, pursued the celestials.

data.v: ततस्तदमृतं देवो विष्णुरादाय वीर्यवान् । जहार दानवेन्द्रेभ्यो नरेण सहितः प्रभुः ॥
data.md: In the meantime the greatly powerful Lord Vishnu, accompanied with Nara, took away the Ambrosia from the mighty Danavas.

data.v: ततो देवगणाः सर्वे पपुस्तदमृतं तदा । विष्णोः सकाशात्संप्राप्य संभ्रमे तुमुले सति ॥
data.md: Thereupon all the celestials, in that great struggle, drank the Ambrosia receiving it from Vishnu.

data.v: ततः पिबत्सु तत्कालं देवेष्वमृतमीप्सितम् । राहुर्विबुधरूपेण दानवः प्रापिबत्तदा ॥
data.md: When the celestials were drinking the much longed-for Ambrosia, a Danava, named Rahu, drank it in the guise of a celestial.

data.v: तस्य कण्ठमनुप्राप्ते दानवस्यामृते तदा । आख्यातं चन्द्रसूर्याभ्यां सुराणां हितकाम्यया ॥
data.md: When the Ambrosia has only reached his throat, Chandra and Surya (recognised him and) informed the celestials of what had happened.

data.v: ततो भगवता तस्य शिरश्छिन्नमलंकृतम् । चक्रायुधेन चक्रेण पिबतोऽमृतमोजसा ॥
data.md: Narayana immediately with his discus cut off the well-adorned head of the Danava who was drinking the Ambrosia.

data.v: तच्छैलशृङ्गप्रतिमं दानवस्य शिरो महत् । चक्रेणोत्कृत्तमपतच्चालयद्वसुधातलम् ॥
data.md: The huge head of the Danava cut off by the discus, appeared like a mountain peak and it rose to the sky and uttered terrible cries.

data.v: ततो वैरविनिर्बन्धः कृतो राहुमुखेन वै । शाश्वतश्चन्द्रसूर्याभ्यां ग्रसत्यद्यापि चैव तौ ॥
data.md: From that day a great enmity was created between the head of Rahu and Chandra and Surya. To this day it swallows Chandra and Surya (causing eclipses.)

data.v: विहाय भगवांश्चापि स्त्रीरूपमतुलं हरिः । नानाप्रहरणैर्भीमैर्दानवान्समकम्पयत् ॥
data.md: Then Hari, quitting his matchless female form, made the Danavas tremble by hurling at them various weapons.

data.v: ततः प्रवृत्तः संग्रामः समीपे लवणाम्भसः । सुराणामसुराणां च सर्वघोरतरो महान् ॥
data.md: Thus began the terrible battle between the Devas and Danavas on the shores of the salt sea.

data.v: प्रासाः सुविपुलास्तीक्ष्णा न्यपतन्त सहस्रशः । तोमराश्च सुतीक्ष्णाग्राः शस्त्राणि विविधानि च ॥
data.md: Thousands of sharp javelins and lances and various other weapons were hurled on all sides.

data.v: ततोऽसुराश्चक्रभिन्ना वमन्तो रुधिरं बहु । असिशक्तिगदारुग्णा निपेतुर्धरणीतले ॥
data.md: Cut by the discus and wounded by swords, darts and maces, the Asuras vomited blood and lay prostrate on earth.

data.v: छिन्नानि पट्टिशैश्चापि शिरांसि युधि दारुणे । तप्तकाञ्चनजालानि निपेतुरनिशं तदा ॥
data.md: The heads, adorned with bright goldchains, cut off by the discus, fell continually in the fearful battle.

data.v: रुधिरेणावलिप्ताङ्गा निहताश्च महासुराः । अद्रीणामिव कूटानि धातुरक्तानि शेरते ॥
data.md: The great Asuras, covered with blood, lay dead everywhere and they looked like red dyed mountain peaks.

data.v: हाहाकारः समभवत्तत्र तत्र सहस्रशः । अन्योन्यं छिन्दतां शस्त्रैरादित्ये लोहितायति ॥
data.md: When the sun grew red, the piteous cries of distress issued from everywhere and from the dying Asuras.

data.v: परिघैश्चायसैः पीतैः संनिकर्षे च मुष्टिभिः । निघ्नतां समरेऽन्योन्यं शब्दो दिवमिवास्पृशत् ॥
